text.p: Here are highlights of stories in Romania's press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:
Business:
BURSA
- Privatisation is the cornerstone of the government's reform programme, the paper says.
- Newspaper says that the Prime Minister used other, yet undisclosed, sources than National Statistics Board (CNS) data.
- Minimum monthly wages will double, paper says.
EVENIMENTUL ZILEI
- Newspaper prints leaked list of companies, including Romanian public television, due to go private or be closed up.
- Paper quotes Finance Minister Mircea Ciumara as saying that the first signs of better living standards will show only in the spring of 1998.
- The head of Canada's TIWC met Prime Minister Victor Ciorbea over the deal to install GSM telephones in Romania.
ADEVARUL
- Newspaper quotes head of the Senate finance and banking commission as saying that international lenders want Romania to limit the budget gap at 5.0 percent of GDP as part of new loan talks.
- Prime Minister Ciorbea meets representatives of 25 leading British and U.S. companies, paper says.
- Paper prints second installment of leaked document on economic data.
ROMANIA LIBERA
- Newspaper prints report by the CNVM securities regulator on investment funds, including the troubled SAFI fund.
CURIERUL NATIONAL
- Several big American and British companies want to invest around $10 billion in Romania, newspaper says.
- The government mulls switching back to the six-day work week.
- The emergence of financial investment companies will bring changes to the capital market.
General:
CURIERUL NATIONAL
- Turkey supports Romania's bid for NATO membership, newspaper quotes Foreign Minister Adrian Severin as saying after his return from Black Sea group meeting.
- Parliament commission will meet next week to decide if Romanians will be allowed to see their files with the defunct communist-era Securitate secret police, paper says.
ROMANIA LIBERA
- Heads of the Romanian Orthodox Church hold annual meeting in former parliament building which was returned to the Church.
-- Bucharest Newsroom 40-1 3120264
